description:
We are running Folsom with nova-network in muti host mode

Compute node A = 192.168.1.10
Compute node B = 192.168.1.11

Doing a live migration of the instance from A -> B works but then the host fails to get a dhcp address.

The iptables rule added to the destination compute node is wrong.

It has:

-A nova-compute-inst-4494 -s 192.168.1.10/32 -p udp -m udp --sport 67 --dport 68 -j ACCEPT

When restarted nova-compute it changes to the correct entry of:

-A nova-compute-inst-4494 -s 192.168.1.11/32 -p udp -m udp --sport 67 --dport 68 -j ACCEPT
title: DHCP fails after live migration when using network multi host

comments.content:
The fix for https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1194178 basically returns functionality back into Folsom that was accidentally removed from Grizzly. To work off of the beginning example:

Compute node A = 192.168.1.10
Compute node B = 192.168.1.11

In Folsom the DHCP iptables rules would be mapped to the host in which the instance is associated. Suppose you booted the instance on node A, then the rule would look like: 

-A instance -s 192.168.1.10/32 -p udp -m udp --sport 67 --dport 68 -j ACCEPT

This rule basically allows DHCP traffic from the nova-network on compute node A: 192.168.1.10. With the introduction of issue 1194178, the DHCP rule would ignore the instance's host and be the ip address of the nova-network that responded to that allocate_address message. In this case, there would be 50/50 chance of it being either 192.168.1.10 or 192.168.1.11. So the fix for 1194178 basically returns the functionality back.

A fix for this issue would be to have the instance look like its had already migrated and on the destination host when acquiring its network_info. This will return back the correct ip address for the DHCP server (the destination host). In this example the instance is migrating from node A to node B. The method "pre_live_migration" is called on node B, which then makes a call to the network API to determine the instance's network info. This info is then used to setup the filtering rules for the instance. Before the call to the network API, the instance object's host field can be modified to be "self.host" (i.e. node B). This will be an in-memory only change and will cause the network API to repsond with the correct DHCP server.

The same dhcp address will be on each network/compute node, 
but only instances on the same node are able to access the address.

comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~wenjianhn

comments.content:
We are running nova-network in multi host mode. That means every host that has nova-compute also has nova-network running on it.
Each compute node acts as a DHCP server for the instances on itself only.
We don't want to have a single DHCP address as that means a single point of failure.
With our set up when a compute node crashes then VMs that aren't running on that node aren't affected.
Does that make sense?
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~sorrison

comments.content:
Yes.

With share_dhcp_address turned on, you do have a single DHCP address.
But the address is added on each compute node, and it is only visible to 
the instances on the same compute node. 

For example, both 192.168.1.2/24 are added as the DHCP address on 
compute node A and compute node B. Whether compute node A crashes
or not, it will not affect instances on compute B. The address is isolated,
instances on compute B will never reach 192.168.1.2 on compute A.
